originalText.text: The City Clerk Office is a straightforward place to have your civil ceremony. They strictly follow the rules and, since Covid, only allow the couple and one witness during the ceremony. If you want to have a photographer, they can act as the witness, but no extra person is permitted. The inside of the office is not particularly special, but there are plenty of beautiful spots outside to take some stunning engagement or wedding photos.

originalText.text: I went here to get a marriage license and that went well. However when I went to register to be an officiant, I followed the instructions but they told me the letter I submitted from my church needed to be on letterhead. It did not say this in the instructions. So the next time I came in with the letter exactly as it said in the instructions. However this time they told me I needed an original signature. It also did not say this in the instructions. The workers there did not seem to have the freedom to act with discretion but just had to follow the bureaucracy. I overheard another guy frustrated saying "I followed the instructions" and he was in the same situation as me. If their website would just say exactly what they needed it would save their workers and the clients a lot of time.

originalText.text: Please hire people that are friendlier and know how to interact with people in a positive way! This shouldn't be a place where employees act like they hate their jobs. I'm sure lots of bad memories were made here on people's wedding day due to rude staff! The service was smooth and efficient in my experience in terms of organization and time management, but the woman who officiated my marriage treated us like we were the biggest inconvenience of her life, so incredibly rude. Didn't ruin my day because we laughed it off. But do these people even recieve training on how to have social ettiquette? I've had waitresses at waffle house treat me better lmao. Social skills should be a basic requirement of being an officiant. Why is this not the case? Please do some sort of social assessment on these people because they might be better off working at McDonalds since they seem to hate what they do.

originalText.text:
My fiancee and I came here on a Wednesday and it was packed due to day being all 8s.  Otherwise, the process is smooth if you have your paperwork.  From security checkpoint to walking out with a Marriage Certificate, it took us two hours.

A lifetime experience and all officials were nice and friendly.

text.text:
My fiancee and I came here on a Wednesday and it was packed due to day being all 8s.  Otherwise, the process is smooth if you have your paperwork.  From security checkpoint to walking out with a Marriage Certificate, it took us two hours.

A lifetime experience and all officials were nice and friendly.

originalText.text:
I came here to get a domestic partnership.  We had to wait about 20 minutes to get in (and go through the security scan and metal detector).  The inside area is very large.

Once we were inside we gave a clerk our IDs and they gave us a number.  We waited another 20 minutes to get called and then sat with another clerk who charged our credit card, and processed our domestic partnership.  Everyone was friendly and the process was pretty easy.

I felt a little strange to be with all the other couples.  And the gift store was a little bit cheesy.  But overall a very pleasant and nice experience.  Consider me happily domestically partnered!
